entry.title: The Type-Writer Girl,
entry.content:
General Notes

  • Genre-bending and and Gender-bending
    • Framing: The Odsessy written by a woman
    • Novella that aspires to be “epic of imagination” (a modern Odyssey), a retelling of opera (Carmen), and a modern pastiche of drama (Romeo and Juliet)
    • Juliet’s use of comic pastiche rather than tragedy
    • Mock transformations of modern London into an epic plane
  • Juliet’s “style”: navigating the “isms” of 19th century through language
    • Use of arch, humorous style as social commentary
      • Juliet dialogically incorporates and ironizes Marxist and Darwinian language: “it was a struggle of self vs. environment. I am unit of the proletariat” (35).
      • the “aforesaids” and “Whereas’s”of the law office are mockingly incorpated into her resignation letter, ads: “Shorthand and Typewriter (female)”
      • Questions of the ambiguity of class of type-writer girl played out in the many different registers of titles for her position: “type-writer girl”, “Lady Type-Writer,” “horrid paragraphist,” “that sort of person,”
    • Language of ads, language of the legal office, Juliet’s “epic” pastiche style
  • “Type-writer girls,” class ambiguity, and class feeling
    • Juliet is miss classed first by the anarchists, then by Mr. Blank
    • Juliet’s ability to recognize characters’ class by their fabrics: cotton-wool, black satin
    • Comic with class signifiers: “I have large estates at Herfordshire…”
    • “Amateur” vs. “Professional” writing
    • Class ambiguity plays out in space.
      • Juliet’s drawing room is the National Art Gallery
      • Questions of class relations complicate gendered spaces: Juliet, because of class is closer to Mr. Blank.
    • Invention of Bohemia: Juliet as educated urban proletariat woman
  • “Meta”-textuality and Juliet’s extradiegetic comments
    • Self conscious narration: reflecting on the story’s lack of love interest (73), on her omissions, on her “failed” epic style
    • Structurally, labor is at the center at the center of the novel
      • The center of the story is on the anarchist camp and the Nicholas icon: labor, capital, ideology (it is only after that that the “This story is deficient in a love interest” line is introduced 73)
      • The ending declaration: I am the type-writer girl = both admission of the cheap romantic tie up to the ordeal AND to her socio-economic situation that forces her to live off writing and selling fiction.
  • Race and national identity
    • Léon (Caliban) and racial anxiety
    • Mr. Blank’s Oriental decor
    • Juliet’s own ambiguous parentage: Gypsy “on my mother’s Lowland Scot or Anglo-Indian” (117); “gypsy or American or Anglo-Indian”(136)

Passages of Note

  • “I have know knack of pathos; even at difficult turns I am apt to see rather the humorous than the tragic side of things” (99)
  • “My life at Romeo’s was a life of routine… All our history is episode, with blanks between, which just serve conveniently to divide the chapters” (85)
  • Woman and machines
    • “A type-writer I was and a type-writer I must remain” (28)
    • “I am a woman first, and a cyclist after”(62)
